page.title: 15Trees of the Hexton Area
page.content: The most common trees are beech, ash, pine and sycamore. Deciduous trees predominate and we noted elder, lime, apple, pear, witch elm, hornbeam, blackthorn, cherry, laurel, silver birch and willow. The evergreen trees are pine, fir and Norwegian spruce. Trees are planted and cultivated to enhance the countryside and to produce commercial crops of firewood and timber for the manufacture of furniture. Forestry is particularly important in squares (29,09) and (29,10). Most trees grow on the steep sides of hills or hilltops where it is difficult to plough the land for cereal crops. In square (29,09) there is a "Site of Special Interest". This is a large clump of beech trees. Nobody is allowed to fell those trees, or to plant more. They are left alone to grow, seed and die naturally.
